<h2>#06 - Writing a single method for arrays or single elements</h2> <blockquote><p>2016-01-06 by <a href="https://twitter.com/mattfxyz">@mattfxyz</a></p></blockquote> <p>Rather than writing separate methods to handle an array and a single element parameter, write your functions so they can handle both. This is similar to how some of jQuery&#39;s functions work (<code>css</code> will modify everything matched by the selector).</p> <p>You just have to concat everything into an array first. <code>Array.concat</code> will accept an array or a single element.</p> <p><code>javascript function printUpperCase(words) { var elements = [].concat(words); for (var i = 0; i &lt; elements.length; i++) { console.log(elements[i].toUpperCase()); } } </code></p> <p><code>printUpperCase</code> is now ready to accept a single node or an array of nodes as its parameter.</p> <p><code>javascript printUpperCase(&quot;cactus&quot;); // =&gt; CACTUS printUpperCase([&quot;cactus&quot;, &quot;bear&quot;, &quot;potato&quot;]); // =&gt; CACTUS // BEAR // POTATO </code></p>
